findings.title: Break-glass accounts with password never expires
findings.description: Break-glass accounts should have regular password rotation. Password never expires increases compromise risk by providing attackers with unlimited time to crack or misuse credentials.
findings.remediation: Implement 90-day password rotation for break-glass accounts. Consider using Microsoft Entra ID Privileged Identity Management for just-in-time access instead.
remediationSteps: Review all break-glass accounts currently in the environment
Enable password expiration policies for break-glass accounts
Enable PIM for just-in-time privileged access
Configure alerts for break-glass account usage

findings.title: Break-glass accounts without MFA
findings.description: Break-glass accounts should have MFA enabled. MFA provides critical protection for emergency access accounts by requiring a second factor even when used from unusual locations.
findings.remediation: Enable MFA on all break-glass accounts using Microsoft Entra ID Conditional Access policies or per-user MFA settings.
remediationSteps: Enable per-user MFA for all break-glass accounts
Configure Conditional Access policy to require MFA for break-glass group
Test break-glass account login with MFA enforcement
Document break-glass account MFA bypass procedures for emergencies

findings.title: Enterprise Admin group has unauthorized members
findings.description: Enterprise Admins group membership should be tightly controlled. Unauthorized members could have domain-wide administrative access.
findings.remediation: Review and remove unauthorized Enterprise Admin memberships. Implement tiered administration model.
remediationSteps: Identify accounts that should not be in Enterprise Admins
Implement tiered admin model to reduce Enterprise Admin scope
Set up monitoring for Enterprise Admin group changes
findings.notes: Detection based on AD group enumeration. Cross-reference with approved access lists recommended.

findings.title: Potential hybrid identity synchronization issues
findings.description: Accounts showing signs of synchronization delays or conflicts between on-premises AD and Entra ID.
findings.remediation: Review Azure AD Connect configuration and health. Investigate synchronization errors.
remediationSteps: Check Azure AD Connect sync health status
Review synchronization error logs in Event Viewer
Check for duplicate proxyAddresses or UPN conflicts
findings.notes: Heuristic-based detection. Manual verification of specific accounts recommended.

highPriorityFindings.title: Break-glass accounts with password never expires

topRemediations.title: Break-glass accounts with password never expires
topRemediations.remediation: Implement 90-day password rotation for break-glass accounts. Consider using Microsoft Entra ID Privileged Identity Management for just-in-time access instead.

topRemediations.remediation: Enable MFA on all break-glass accounts using Microsoft Entra ID Conditional Access policies or per-user MFA settings.

notes: This report was generated using IdentityFirst QuickChecks version 1.1.0
Confidence levels: High (direct evidence, multiple sources), Medium (some corroboration), Low (inferred/heuristic)
Evidence quality: Direct (directory queries), Indirect (API responses), Inferred (calculated)
Reliability scores above 80% indicate high-confidence findings suitable for immediate action
Findings with Low confidence or Inferred evidence should be verified manually before remediation
